Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Nanoprecipitation - Scalable Production of Polymeric Nanoparticles Encapsulating Hydrophobic Compounds

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Early Faculty Career Development (CAREER) Program award provides funding to achieve a comprehensive understanding of the competitive kinetics required to reproducibly generate polymeric nanoparticles encapsulating hydrophobic drugs with optimized physicochemical properties. Polymeric nanoparticles as drug carriers can dramatically increase the solubility and bioavailability of hydrophobic compounds due to their large surface to volume ratio. The major challenge of developing polymeric nanoparticles for clinical applications is the production at larger scale while maintaining consistent nanoparticle properties. Due to the complexity of the process, purely empirical optimization is infeasible and quantitative prediction by a judicious interplay of simulations and experiments is essential. Time-resolved small-angle X-ray scattering integrated with a microfluidic device will be employed to experimentally observe nanoparticle structural evolution in situ. Computational fluid dynamics modeling together with population balance equations will be developed to numerically understand the coupling of mixing with precipitation. Iteration between modeling and experiments will lead to a fundamental understanding of how nanoparticle systems form, thus making it possible to efficiently design, optimize, and scale up nanoparticle production.

If successful, a scalable method of nanoparticle production will have been developed, which will lead to rapid clinical translation of a variety of nanocarrier systems to deliver hydrophobic drugs and to detect and treat complex diseases. The experimental and numerical methods can be used as a platform to optimize conditions for dispersed multi-phase reactions in general. The state-of-the-art experimental observation of nanoparticle structural evolution with sub-second time resolution will greatly enhance our understanding of precipitation kinetics and nanoparticle production. The study will be integrated into the courses developed by the PI as well as into various educational activities targeting graduate, undergraduate, and 6-12 students in an interdisciplinary setting. The highly visual nature of the experimental and theoretical results and the societal relevance of the biomedical applications represent a natural draw for recruiting students to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) disciplines.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Outcomes

The objective of this funded CAREER research is to achieve a comprehensive understanding of the competitive kinetics required to reproducibly generate polymeric nanoparticles encapsulating hydrophobic drugs in a scalable manner. Nearly 40% of all pharmaceutical compounds on the market and 90% of the newly developed ones are hydrophobic, and therefore difficult to deliver and to maintain at sufficient bioavailability. Polymeric nanoparticles as drug carriers can dramatically increase the solubility and bioavailability of hydrophobic compounds due to their large surface to volume ratio. The major challenge of translating polymeric nanoparticles to clinical applications is the production at larger scale while maintaining consistent nanoparticle properties, e.g. drug loading, size distribution, and surface functionality. Through this funded research, a continuous, scalable process was developed to generate stable polymeric nanoparticles encapsulating hydrophobic compounds. State-of-the-art measurements were employed to characterize the fast kinetics of polymer micellization which is critical for judicious design and optimization of nanoparticle structures. More specifically, the following accomplishments directly resulted from this research project (#1350731) funded by NSF Nanomanufacturing program.

In situ Measurements of Polymer Micellization Kinetics

The drug-loaded polymeric nanoparticles are at metastable state, not at global equilibrium, and their physicochemical properties (such as size and drug loading) depend on the path of generating the nanoparticles. Because of the enormous number of possible combinations of polymer blocks (such as molecular structures, composition of each block, and molecular weight of each block) and the operation conditions (such as solvent to antisolvent ratio, flow rate, pH, temperature, and the choices of the solvents), the self-assembly kinetics of block copolymer micellization could be tailored in endless ways. Knowing these polymers? micellization kinetics is essential for optimizing nanostructures in a rational manner, producing polymeric and polymer-hybrid nanoparticles for biomedical and biological applications. By utilizing synchrotron small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) (at BioCAT, 18ID, at the Advanced Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory) integrated with a custom-made microfluidic device, the micellization kinetics of a diblock copolymer was measured in situ with millisecond temporal and micrometer spatial resolution. The evolutionary regimes of polymer micellization ? nucleation, fusion, and insertion were individually directly observed. The technique of integrating SAXS with microfluidic devices can be translatable to other systems for a breadth of applications.

Production of Nanoparticles for Biomedical Applications

Polymeric nanoparticles and hybrid polymer-lipid particles encapsulating active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) (including SR13668, M3MP6 peptide, capecitabine and its analogues, pazopanib, docetaxel, and curcumin) were generated and characterized using the method developed through the support of this grant. Nanoparticles of these APIs produced in the Liu laboratory have the desired physicochemical properties and also long-term stability. The biomedical advantages of using these nanoparticles encapsulating the APIs for sustained drug release, enhanced bioavailability, and targeting delivery to the disease sites were demonstrated. By this continuous process of flash nanoprecipitation, large-scale production with high re-producibility of the nanoformulations is possible for clinical applications of the drug compounds.

Measurements of Interfacial Molecular Packing and Interactions

In order to understand the behavior of molecules at the interface during nanoparticle self-assembly and drug release, molecular packing of the lipids, polymers, and drug compounds at the gas-aqueous interface and their interactions with a model enzyme were systematically studied by employing the X-ray reflectivity and grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXD) at the NSF?s ChemMatCARS (15ID C) at APS of the Argonne National Laboratory integrated with a custom-made Langmuir trough. The results of this study will advance our understanding of the roles of enzymes in related physiological processes, and lead to a mechanism-based approach to designing and optimizing pro-drug molecules and polymer-lipid-based nanomedicines.

Educational Outcomes

The long-term educational goal of the PI is to recruit and mentor underrepresented minority and female students in STEM disciplines. This research project provided graduate and undergraduate students with interdisciplinary career-development opportunities to learn and apply computer simulations, advanced biomaterials techniques, and material characterization skills. Seven PhD students (among whom 5 students are minorities or women and 3 graduated and have been working in material or biotech companies) and ten undergraduate students (among whom 7 students are minorities or women, 2 have been admitted to graduate schools, and 5 have been working in chemical and pharmaceutical companies) were supported by the grant. To disseminate the results of the research, eight research articles and a book chapter were published, and research findings were presented at national annual conferences by the graduate and undergraduate students. One patent application has been filed for this technology (Nanoparticles and Methods of Producing the same).

In summary, the results of this study provide the key fundamental-science basis for a scalable way of manufacturing nanoparticles with well-defined structures and physical chemical properties encapsulating hydrophobic drug compounds, which provide unique biomedical advantages and functionalities. The experimental techniques and data analysis can be used as a platform for optimization of conditions for nanomaterial production in general.


Last Modified: 04/15/2020
Modified by: Ying Liu

Nearly 40% of all pharmaceutical compounds on the market and 90% of the newly developed ones are hydrophobic, and therefore difficult to deliver and to maintain at sufficient bioavailability.
